Scheme 1 Oxidation of DBT to DBTO2 by H2O2 in the presence of [HMIm]BF4. Scheme 2 Mechanism details for the oxidation of DBT to DBTO2 by H2O2 in the absence of [HMIm]BF4, summarized from the present calculations. Scheme 3 Mechanism details for DBT oxidation to DBTO2 by H2O2 with the assistance of the ionic pair. Fig. 1 Optimized geometries at the B3LYP/6-311++G(d,p) level for isolated H2O2, DBT, BF4 anion, and [HMIm] cation. Bond distances are in angstrom, and the angles are in degree. The values in parentheses are experimental results. Fig. 2 (a) Energies of the HOMO and LUMO orbitals of H2O2 and DBT, (b) LUMO isosurface of H2O2, and (c) HOMO isosurface of DBT. Fig. 3 Calculated energy profile for the oxidation of DBT to DBTO2 by H2O2 in the absence of [HMIm]BF4 with the optimized geometries of transition states (TS1 and TS2). The total energy of reactants (DBT+2H2O2) is taken as the zero energy. Distances are given in angstroms. Fig. 4 Two most stable geometries of the complex between the ionic pair and H2O2. Distances are in angstrom. Fig. 5 Calculated energy profiles for the oxidation of DBT to DBTO2 by H2O2 with the assistance of the ionic pair. The total energy of reactants (the ionic pair, DBT, and 2H2O2) is taken as the zero energy. Fig. 6 Optimized geometries of transition states involved in pathways (a) and (b). Distances are given in angstroms. The values in parentheses denote the imaginary frequencies of the transition states. Fig. 7 Optimized geometries for the complexes of DBT and DBTO2 with the cation, anion, and ion pair. Distances are shown in angstrom. The values in square brackets are the calculated interaction energies (inkcalmol−1). Theoretical elucidation of the dual role of [HMIm]BF4 ionic liquid as catalyst and extractant in the oxidative desulfurization of dibenzothiophene Hao Xu a Zhe Han b Dongju Zhang a ⁎ Chengbu Liu a a Key Laboratory of Colloid and Interface Chemistry, Ministry of Education, Institute of Theoretical Chemistry, Shandong University, Jinan 250100, PR China Key Laboratory of Colloid and Interface Chemistry Ministry of Education Institute of Theoretical Chemistry Shandong University Jinan 250100 PR China b New Material Institute of Shandong Academy of Sciences, Jinan 250014, PR China New Material Institute of Shandong Academy of Sciences Jinan 250014 PR China ⁎ Corresponding author. Tel.: +86 531 88365833; fax: +86 531 88564464. Graphical abstract While the oxidative desulfurization (ODS) of aromatic sulfur compounds, such as dibenzothiophene (DBT), in ionic liquids (ILs) has attracted great attention, the role of ILs is still not well elucidated at the molecular level. Focusing on a model system, i.e., the ODS of DBT using H2O2 as oxidant in 1-methylimidazolium tetrafluoroborate ([HMIm]BF4) IL, this work presents a theoretical elucidation of the dual role of IL as a catalyst and an extractant by performing density functional theory calculations. It is found that as a catalyst, both the cation and anion of the IL play important roles in the oxidation process of DBT to dibenzothiophene sulfone (DBTO2): they act respectively, as the donor of one intermolecular hydrogen bond and the acceptor of another intermolecular hydrogen bond to promote the OO and OH cleavages of H2O2 and to stabilize transition state structures. With the assistance of the IL, the barriers of two elementary steps involved in the transformation from DBT to DBTO2 are reduced to 13.1 and 23.8kcalmol−1 from 32.1 and 37.8kcalmol−1, respectively. On the other hand, as an extractant both the cation and anion of IL show stronger interactions with DBTO2 than with DBT, which is attributed to the larger polarity of the former than the latter. Furthermore, calculated interaction energies of the cation–molecule complexes are larger than those of the anion–molecule complexes, indicating that the cation plays a more important role in the extraction and separation process of aromatic sulfur compound from fuels. Keywords Dibenzothiophene Oxidative desulfurization Hydrogen peroxide 1-Methylimidazolium tetrafluoroborate DFT 1 Introduction Exhaust gases containing SO x are a major cause of air pollution and acid rain, and may lead to many serious diseases of human respiratory system. The standard for sulfur content in fuels is becoming more and more stringent worldwide. Many countries have made laws or regulations to restrict the sulfur content in fuel oil in order to protect the environment against SOx pollution [1]. As a result, the desulfurization of fuels has attracted much attention in the last decade [2,3]. Catalytic hydrodesulfurization (HDS) is a conventional method in industry to reduce the sulfur level in fuels. In this process, the organic sulfur components of fuels are catalytically converted to H2S and the corresponding hydrocarbons [4–8]. HDS is highly effective for removal of aliphatic sulfur-containing compounds, including thiols, thioethers, and disulfides. However, aromatic sulfur compounds such as dibenzothiophene (DBT) and its derivatives are very difficult to be removed by the conventional HDS method because of the low reactivity of these sulfur compounds in the HDS reaction [9,10]. Furthermore, there are many disadvantages of the conventional HDS method, such as severe conditions of high temperature and high pressure, as well as high costs of equipment and hydrogen. In recent years, some alternative methods are being developed, including oxidative desulfurization (ODS) [11,12], biodesulfurization [13], adsorptive [14] and extractive desulfurization [15]. Among various new desulfurization methods, ODS has attracted special interests because it can be carried out under mild conditions without the presence of H2. Currently, this method is being considered as a promising approach to produce ultra-low sulfur diesel. Ionic liquids (ILs) are low melting organic salts that are generally composed of large organic cations (such as alkylimidazolium, alkylpyridimium, and tetraalkylammonium) and small inorganic anions (such as Cl−, NO3 −, BF4 −, and PF6 −) [16–18]. Over the past decade, ILs have been attracted more and more attention [19–22] due to their remarkable physicochemical properties [23–26], such as high thermal and chemical stability, negligible vapor pressure, reusability, and designablility, which make ILs widely used in chemical synthesis and extraction separation processes. A considerable amount of literature has been published on the application of ILs [27–30]. In recent years, many literatures have reported that ILs could be used in the desulfurization process of fuels. Initially, ILs were used as extractants to directly extract thiophene sulfides from fuels [1,31,32]. However, the sulfur removal efficiency is found to be rather low because of the similar polarity between the sulfur-containing compounds and alkenes and aromatics. Subsequently, extractive desulfurization using ILs was combined into the ODS method to improve the efficiency of the sulfur removal. In the IL-based extractive/oxidative system, ozone and/or hydrogen peroxide are generally used as oxidants, which oxidizes sulfur compounds to sulfoxides and sulfones, and some acidic ILs, such as 1-methylimidazolium tetrafluoroborate ([HMIm]BF4), N-methyl-pyrrolidonium tetrafluoroborate ([Hnmp]BF4), and 1-butyl-3-methylimidazolium hydrogen sulfate ([BMIm]HSO4), are selected as the extractants [33–36]. It is found that acidic ILs used in the ODS processes also play a role of catalyst for the sulfur compound oxidation. Although IL-based ODS has been successfully achieved, the details of the mechanism are still ambiguous and worthy of further exploration. Theoretical study based on quantum chemistry can provide molecular-level information of catalytic reaction processes. In the present work, our interest focuses on the mechanistic aspect of the ODS in the presence of ILs. [HMIm]BF4 was chosen as a representative of acidic ILs because it was found to provide highly effective sulfur removal and is more superior to the generally used ILs that act as extractants in the ODS processes [34]. We studied the detailed mechanism of oxidizing DBT into dibenzothiophene sulfone (DBTO2) by H2O2 with the assistance of [HMIm]BF4 IL (Scheme 1 ). Our aim is to explore the dual role of extractant and catalyst of the IL in the ODS process, and hence, to provide a reasonable explanation for experimental observations. 2 Computational details The present calculations were carried out with the Gaussian 03 program package [37]. It is well known that the density functional theory (DFT) [38–41] method offers an excellent compromise between the computational cost and accuracy of the computational outcomes. In this work, all calculations were performed in the framework of DFT at the B3LYP/6-311++G(d,p) level of theory. All structures for the reactants, products, intermediates, and transition states have been fully optimized without any symmetry constraints. Vibrational frequencies were also calculated for all optimized geometries at the same level of theory to identify the natures of the stationary points as minima (no imaginary vibrations) or transition states (one imaginary vibration) and to provide the zero-point vibrational energies (ZPEs). The intrinsic reaction coordinate (IRC) [42,43] calculations were performed in both directions (forward and reverse) from transition states to the corresponding local minima to identify the minimum-energy paths. ZPE corrections have been taken into account for all the cited energies. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Calibration calculations In order to support our choice for the functional and basis set, the benchmark calculations were first carried out for several isolated species, H2O2, DBT, BF4 anion, and [HMIm] cation, for which experimental geometrical parameters are available. Fig. 1 compares the calculated results with the experimental counterparts. It is noted that the optimized geometrical parameters are in good agreement with the experimental values [44–47], indicating the reliability of the calculation method used for investigating the present system. 3.2 Frontier molecular orbitals of H2O2 and DBT According to the frontier molecular orbital (FMO) theory [48], it is known that the reactivity between two molecules is inversely proportional to the energy difference between the highest occupied molecular orbital (HOMO) of one molecule and the lowest unoccupied molecular orbital (LUMO) of the other. The smaller the value of the HOMO−LUMO energy difference is, the more reactive the chemical reaction will be. The HOMO and LUMO energy levels of H2O2 and DBT are shown in Fig. 2 a. Obviously, the energy difference between HOMODBT and LUMOH2O2 (5.49eV) is smaller than the difference between HOMOH2O2 and LUMODBT (6.59eV). Thus, the oxidation of DBT by H2O2 proceeds via the HOMODBT–LUMOH2O2 interaction. Fig. 2b and c shows the LUMO isosurface of H2O2 and the HOMO isosurface of DBT, which are largely localized at O atoms and S atom, respectively. These areas are expected to be the active sites of the reaction. 3.3 Oxidation of DBT by H2O2 in the absence of [HMIm]BF4 In order to make a comparison with the catalyzed reaction, we first performed calculations about the oxidation of DBT by H2O2 in the absence of [HMIm]BF4. It should be kept in mind that such a process does not describe a real system and it was only used as a reference against the process with the presence of [HMIm]BF4. Based on the theoretical results, we have summarized the reaction process in Scheme 2 . The reaction proceeds through two elementary steps: DBT→DBTO→DBTO2 (Scheme 2). Fig. 3 shows the calculated energy profile along the reaction coordinate, where the optimized geometries of transition states (TS1 and TS2) are provided. The geometries of DBT, intermediate complexes (COM1–COM4), and DBTO2 are given in Fig. S1 in the Supplementary data. Initially, the van der Waals interaction between DBT and H2O2 results in the formation of COM1 with a binding energy of 2.4kcalmol−1. We have considered various possible orientations between DBT and H2O2, including the S atom of DBT binds to the O atom of H2O2. However, the calculated results show that the SO bonding structure is unstable. From COM1, DBT was converted to DBTO in COM2 via the transition state TS1. This process corresponds to the oxidation of DBT to DBTO. Note that COM2 is a complex between DBTO and H2O. The formation of COM2 is calculated to be exothermic by 27.9kcalmol−1 with a barrier of 32.1kcalmol−1. TS1 is a three-membered ring transition state (O1H1O2, Fig. 3), where O1H1 (0.993Å) and O1O2 (2.026Å) bonds are breaking while O1S (2.009Å) and H1O2 (1.577Å) bonds are forming. Subsequently, to carry out the transformation from DBTO to DBTO2, COM2 first releases a water molecule and then links a second H2O2 molecule to form van der Waals complex between DBTO and H2O2, COM3, which is then converted to COM4 via transition state TS2. The mechanism is found to be similar to that involved in the first step (DBT→DBTO) but with slightly different relative energy profile. The barrier for the transformation from DBTO to DBTO2 is calculated to be 37.0kcalmol−1. Clearly, two elementary steps shown in Scheme 2 and Fig. 3 involve high barriers (27.9 and 37.0kcalmol−1), implying that oxidizing DBT to DBTO2 by H2O2 without the assistance of a catalyst cannot occur under room temperature conditions. These results are in agreement with the experimental finding. 3.4 Oxidation of DBT by H2O2 with the assistance of [HMIm]BF4 In this section, we will investigate the reaction of DBT with H2O2 in the presence of [HMIm]BF4 IL. One ionic pair of [HMIm]BF4 is used to mimic the IL surrounding. For a catalytic reaction, substrate binding to catalyst is an essential and initial step. In the present situation, the interaction of the ionic pair with H2O2 is expected to be stronger than that with DBT because of the possible presence of the effective OH⋯F hydrogen bond in the former. So we first optimized the complex structures between the ionic pair and H2O2. Fig. 4 shows the two most stable geometries. As expected, these two geometries contain OH⋯F hydrogen bonds with distances of 1.759 and 1.774Å, respectively. Furthermore, it is observed that H2O2 also interacts with the cation via a relatively weaker CH⋯O (2.187Å) hydrogen bond in structure (a) or NH⋯O (2.238Å) hydrogen bond in structure (b). The bind energies of these two structures are calculated to be 11.7 and 9.9kcalmol−1, relative to the sum of energies of a free H2O2 and an isolated ion pair, respectively. Starting from these two structures, we calculated two possible pathways of the oxidation of DBT to DBTO2, pathways (a) and (b), which start from structure (a) and (b) in Fig. 4, respectively. Scheme 3 summarizes the calculated mechanism details, and Fig. 5 shows the relevant energy profiles. The relevant transition states are presented in Fig. 6 , and the corresponding intermediates and products are shown in Fig. S2 in the Supplementary data. Both two pathways involve a mechanism qualitatively similar to that described for the reaction in the absence of the ionic pair, i.e., the reaction proceeds via two elementary steps: DBT is first oxidized to DBTO and then to DBTO2. In Scheme 3 and Fig. 5, the stationary points on the potential energy surface are marked with symbols similar to those in Scheme 2: one or two apostrophes in each symbol denote the structures involved in pathway (a) or pathway (b). As seen in Scheme 3, the main difference of pathways (a) and (b) is the different orientations of imidazolium ring: H2O2 interacts with the C2H bond in pathway (a) whereas with the N3H bond in pathway (b). Calculated results indicate that pathway (b) is energetically more favorable than pathway (a). So in the following discussion, our attention mainly focuses on pathway (b) for simplification. As shown in Scheme 3, COM1″ in pathway (b) is a three-molecular complex of the ionic pair, H2O2, and DBT formed via hydrogen bonds and van der Waals interactions. It is identified to be more stable by 13.3kcalmol−1 than the isolated reactants (the ionic pair, 2H2O2, DBT). Along the reaction coordinate, DBT in COM1′′ is oxidized to DBTO in COM2′′ through the transition state TS1′′ with a barrier of 13.1kcalmol−1. COM2′′ is calculated to be 33.9kcalmol−1 more stable than COM1′′. In TS1′′, the nucleophilic O atom in H2O2 is attacking the electron-deficient S atom in DBT to produce DBTO in COM2′′. Subsequently, a second H2O2 is introduced into the system to form COM3′′, a three molecular complex of the ionic pair, H2O2, and DBTO, which is located at almost exactly the same energy as COM2′′. DBTO in COM3′′ is further oxidized to DBTO2 via TS2′′ with a barrier of 23.8kcalmol−1 and a reaction heat of 48.8kcalmol−1. The overall reaction for oxidation of DBT to DBTO2 is calculated to be strongly exothermic (−96.6kcalmol−1), indicating that there is a strong driving force for transformation DBT→DBTO2 and the reaction is irreversible. As seen from pathway (b) in Fig. 5, with the assistance of the ionic pair, all species involved in the oxidation of DBT to DBTO2 lie below the reaction entrance. This situation is essentially different from the reaction without the presence of the ionic pair, where two transition states (TS1 and TS2) involved in the oxidation of DBT lie above the reaction entrance. Furthermore, the barriers of two elementary steps are reduced to 13.1 and 23.8kcalmol−1 from 32.1 and 37.0kcalmol−1, respectively (cf. Fig. 5 and Fig. 3). These results indicate the IL plays a substantially important role, which stabilizes all species involved in the reaction, in particular, the transition states, through the hydrogen bonding interaction between the ion and molecule. As shown by the structural parameters of transition states in Fig. 6, the cation of IL acts as the donor of one intermolecular hydrogen bond, whereas the anion is the acceptor of another intermolecular hydrogen bond. These intermolecular hydrogen bonds not only promote the OO and OH cleavages of H2O2 but also significantly stabilize transition state structures, and hence make the oxidation of DBT to DBTO2 proceed smoothly at room temperature, as observed in experiments [33–36]. 3.5 Extraction and separation mechanism As mentioned in the introduction, ODS involves a two-step process of oxidation and extraction. We now turn to understanding the role of the IL as an effective extractant. We would like to explain why the IL shows a good extraction ability for DBTO2 but does not for DBT. DBT is a symmetric, planar, and almost non-polar molecule, and its dipole moment is calculated to be only 0.78D. In contrast, DBTO2 is a highly polar molecule with a dipole moment of 5.77D. Thus, the interaction of DBTO2 with the IL is expected to be stronger than DBT, making DBTO2 readily extracted into the IL phase and hence enhancing the extraction efficiency. Fig. 7 shows the most stable structures of complexes of DBT and DBTO2 with the cation, anion, and the ionic pair. For the cation–molecule complexes (Fig. 7a and b), the cation interacts with DBT through NH⋯S (2.375Å) hydrogen bond and with DBTO2 through NH⋯O (1.741Å) and CH⋯O (2.326Å) hydrogen bonds. The calculated interaction energy is 12.2kcalmol−1 for the former and 26.1kcalmol−1 for the latter, indicating the much stronger capturing ability of the cation for DBTO2 than for DBT. For the anion-molecule complexes (Fig. 7c and d), it is found that both DBT and DBTO2 mainly interact with the anion through their CH units to form furcated CH⋯F hydrogen bonds, and bond distances vary from 2.1 to 3.0Å. The calculated interaction energies of DBT and DBTO2 with the anion are 9.4 and 16.1kcalmol −1 , respectively. The larger interaction energy of DBTO2 with the anion can be attributed to the large electronegativity of O atoms and hence its much larger dipole moment than DBT (5.77 vs. 0.78D), leading to the stronger dipole interaction with the anion and inducing the H atoms on the benzene ring become more electropositive, which in turn strengthen its hydrogen-bonding interaction with the anion. This indicates that the anion also shows stronger capturing ability to DBTO2 than to DBT. Furthermore, it is noted that the calculated interaction energy (26.1kcalmol−1) for the complex of DBTO2 with the cation is obviously much larger than that (16.1kcalmol−1) with the anion. Thus, we believe that the cation of IL plays a crucial role in the extraction and separation process of DBTO2 from fuels. The complex structures of the ion pair with DBT and DBTO2 are presented in Fig. 7e and f. Clearly, these two structures reserve hydrogen bonding features in the cation– and anion–molecule complexes. DBT mainly interacts with ion pair through CH⋯S (3.282Å) and CH⋯F (2.314 and 2.339Å) hydrogen bonding, and DBTO2 links to the ion pair via CH⋯O and CH⋯F hydrogen bonding. The calculated interaction energies of DBT and DBTO2 with the ion pair are 6.6 and 11.9kcalmol−1, respectively. Again, DBTO2 presents stronger interaction with the ion pair than DBT. According to these results, we can have a better understanding on the higher extraction efficiency of the IL for DBTO2 than for DBT. From the present calculated mechanism, it is clear that both the cation and anion of [HMIm]BF4 play important roles in the oxidation process of DBT to dibenzothiophene sulfone (DBTO2). The cation and anion act respectively as the donor and acceptor of intermolecular hydrogen bonds. We consider the mechanism shown in this work for [HMIm]BF4 may also be applied to the acidic ionic liquids where the anion can act as a acceptor of intermolecular hydrogen bond, such as Cl−. 4 Conclusions In this paper, we have carried out a detailed theoretical study to better understand the mechanism of oxidative–extractive desulfurization of DBT from fuels by [HMIm]BF4 IL in the presence of H2O2. Our DFT calculations have shown clearly the dual role of the IL as catalyst and extractant. As a catalyst, the IL significantly reduces the barriers of two elementary steps involved in the oxidation of DBT to DBTO2. And as an extractant, both the cation and anion of the IL show stronger interactions with DBTO2 than with DBT, explaining enhanced extraction efficiency of the IL for the former than for the latter. Furthermore, calculated larger interaction energies of the cation–molecule complexes than the anion–molecule complexes indicate that the cation plays a more important role in the extraction and separation process of aromatic sulfur compounds from fuels. The present results provide guidance for understanding the oxidative–extractive ODS by acidic ionic liquids in the presence of H2O2. coredata.dc:description: While the oxidative desulfurization (ODS) of aromatic sulfur compounds, such as dibenzothiophene (DBT), in ionic liquids (ILs) has attracted great attention, the role of ILs is still not well elucidated at the molecular level. Focusing on a model system, i.e., the ODS of DBT using H2O2 as oxidant in 1-methylimidazolium tetrafluoroborate ([HMIm]BF4) IL, this work presents a theoretical elucidation of the dual role of IL as a catalyst and an extractant by performing density functional theory calculations. It is found that as a catalyst, both the cation and anion of the IL play important roles in the oxidation process of DBT to dibenzothiophene sulfone (DBTO2): they act respectively, as the donor of one intermolecular hydrogen bond and the acceptor of another intermolecular hydrogen bond to promote the OO and OH cleavages of H2O2 and to stabilize transition state structures. With the assistance of the IL, the barriers of two elementary steps involved in the transformation from DBT to DBTO2 are reduced to 13.1 and 23.8kcalmol−1 from 32.1 and 37.8kcalmol−1, respectively. On the other hand, as an extractant both the cation and anion of IL show stronger interactions with DBTO2 than with DBT, which is attributed to the larger polarity of the former than the latter. Furthermore, calculated interaction energies of the cation–molecule complexes are larger than those of the anion–molecule complexes, indicating that the cation plays a more important role in the extraction and separation process of aromatic sulfur compound from fuels.
coredata.dc:title: Theoretical elucidation of the dual role of [HMIm]BF4 ionic liquid as catalyst and extractant in the oxidative desulfurization of dibenzothiophene
